message: The next movie on my list to watch after The Wedding Banquet is Social Network. I can provide opinion by this weekend.

I saw The Social Network described as "about a brilliant young man who creates a virtual network to replace the one that rejected him at Harvard." 

It's hard to deny that he does build a virtual network and that he is rejected by the final clubs, but I'm not sure this matters to the drama of the movie. (Would it have been the same if he'd written DOS, and it was set in the 80s?) Yes, the two things "resonate" but I think, so what?
I see what you're saying.  I think its just a clever bit of copywriting for the DVD box
